title: George F. Whitworth
text:
George Frederick Whitworth (March 15, 1816 – October 6, 1907) was a <a href="Presbyterian">Presbyterian</a> missionary, educated at <a href="Hanover%20College">Hanover College</a> in Indiana. Whitworth worked a minister in the Ohio Valley until 1853, when he and his family moved to the Western frontier. 
In 1867, he co-founded the Lake Washington Coal Company. He was active in the founding of the first church in <a href="Grand%20Mound%2C%20Washington">Grand Mound, Washington</a>, which he co-pastored with J. W. Goodell (father of pioneer <a href="Phoebe%20Judson">Phoebe Judson</a>). He was the president of the <a href="University%20of%20Washington">University of Washington</a> from 1866–67 and 1874–76, and was the founder of Whitworth College (now <a href="Whitworth%20University">Whitworth University</a>) in 1890. 
Grave.
He is buried at <a href="Lake%20View%20Cemetery%20%28Seattle%29">Lake View Cemetery</a>, <a href="Seattle%2C%20Washington">Seattle, Washington</a>. His grave is an <a href="American%20Presbyterian%20and%20Reformed%20Historic%20Site">American Presbyterian and Reformed Historic Site</a> (No. 252) registered by the <a href="Presbyterian%20Historical%20Society">Presbyterian Historical Society</a>, headquartered in Philadelphia.
